Title: Google's reCAPTCHA test has been tricked by artificial intelligence - WIRED
description: Part of Google's reCAPTCHA test has been fooled by reinforcement learning – but the latest version of the system hasn't been fully hacked yet
keywords: ['business', 'ai hub', 'artificial intelligence', 'security', 'google', '_wired-uk-migrated', 'web']
og:description: Part of Google's reCAPTCHA test has been fooled by reinforcement learning – but the latest version of the system hasn't been fully hacked yet
twitter:description: Part of Google's reCAPTCHA test has been fooled by reinforcement learning – but the latest version of the system hasn't been fully hacked yet
article text: Nicole KobieBusinessMar 25, 2019 2:00 AMGoogle's reCAPTCHA test has been tricked by artificial intelligencePart of Google's reCAPTCHA test has been fooled by reinforcement learning – but the latest version of the system hasn't been fully hacked yetSave this storySaveSave this storySaveComputer scientists have found a way around Google's reCAPTCHA tests, tricking the system into thinking an artificial intelligence program is human. But there's a catch, although the AI system can fool the bot test it doesn't live-up to the promise its creators give it.CAPTCHAs are the tests used by websites to battle back against bots, asking website visitors to prove they're human before proceeding. The leading system is Google's reCAPTCHA, which has previously asked website visitors to prove their humanity by checking words scanned from books or photographs of street signs. That was replaced with behavioural analysis, requiring humans to simply tick a box proclaiming "I'm not a robot".Such systems have been hacked before. Indeed, the text and image based CAPTCHAs have been so frequently cracked that researchers in China and Lancaster University dubbed their paper on generative adversarial networks "Yet another text CAPTCHA solver". The accessible audio version was even targeted using speech-to-text tools to listen to the audio clips and upload an answer.Trending NowMoistCr1TiKaL Answers The Web's Most Searched QuestionsBut that all got harder at the end of last year, when Google revealed a CAPTCHA-less reCAPTCHA. Rather than unpicking garbled text or street signs, or even ticking a box that a website visitor is not a robot, version 3 of reCAPTCHA analyses a range of signals, giving a score between zero and one. Lower scores are more likely to be bots, while higher scores are more likely  to be human.That ranking happens entirely in the background; there's no human interaction at all. Google hasn't explained what goes into the bot-or-not score — no surprise, as hackers would be sure to make use of that information — but it appears to include the browser used, IP address, and whether they're logged into a Google account. After all, if Google knows it's you, it knows you're not a bot.That system hasn't yet been hacked, despite the title claim of the authors of a recent paper, "Hacking Google reCAPTCHA v3 using Reinforcement Learning." Instead, Mohamed Akrout, of the University of Toronto, and his co-authors focused on tricking a secondary system with machine learning. The invisible scoring system isn't abused, but nevertheless they claim they could still get past reCAPTCHA v3.AdvertisementIn reCAPTCHA v3, websites set their own score threshold for what they are willing to consider a bot or not. If a visitor falls under that threshold at a set point, such as when they're entering a review or login details, the website has two options, says Akrout. The first is to immediately show a page denouncing that visitor as a bot, which is a little awkward if the system is wrong and it's a human; imagine working your way through an online purchase to suddenly have the page you're looking at disappear and be shown a "You're a bot" accusation out of nowhere. "This is a bad practice from a user experience perspective," says Akrout.Instead, Akrout says, many sites choose to negotiate the process a little more kindly. If a website visitor falls below the bot-or-not threshold, the site will surface a page with the older style "I am not a robot" checkbox, letting humans better understand why their online shopping experience or whatever else was interrupted and giving them a chance to prove their humanity.  "Most programmers I know add checkboxes because they don't know how to choose a time at which they ask v3 about its belief." By that, he means that version 3 has a constant score; websites can access it at any time. Do it at random, and a site will suddenly stop working.Most PopularThe Big StoryPriscila, Queen of the Rideshare MafiaBy Lauren Smiley, WIREDPoliticsTrump Shooting Conspiracies Are Coming From Every DirectionBy David Gilbert, WIREDPoliticsFar-Right Extremists Call for Violence and War After Trump ShootingBy David Gilbert, WIREDSecurityAT&T Paid a Hacker $370,000 to Delete Stolen Phone RecordsBy Kim Zetter, WIREDRead more: Captcha is dying. This is how it's being reinvented for the AI ageAnd it's in that gap that Akrout and his fellow researchers strike. The "I am not a robot" checkbox was introduced in version 2 of reCAPTCHA, analysing behaviour including mouse movements to spot bots. The researchers have created an automated system that can fool that part of reCAPTCHA.It's not directly addressing version 3's invisible scoring, but the mouse-movement analysis first introduced in version 2 — but because of how the system is implemented on some websites, it doesn't have to fool the newer system. In other words, they've found another way around reCAPTCHA using AI but it isn't quite as grand as promised.That doesn't convince Nan Jiang of the University of Bournemouth, who wasn't involved with this research. "Theoretically, any CAPTCHA scheme purely relying on examining user behaviour can be hacked with tailored machine learning algorithms as such algorithms can be used to simulate a real user’s interaction on a page easily," he notes. "However, Google ReCAPTCHA… combines other technologies to predict how much a client can be trusted and then try to whitelist that client. Once you get whitelisted, whatever you do will still allow you to pass the test."Akrout and his fellow researchers fool the one section of reCAPTCHA using a type of machine learning called reinforcement learning, in which a software agent tries to find the best possible path, encouraged via rewards for each step it takes in the right direction. Their system lays a grid of squares across the page, working the mouse diagonally through the grid towards the "I am not a robot button". Given positive reinforcement if it's successful and negative if not, the system learns the right ways to move to convince reCAPTCHA the mouse is being controlled. The paper claims it works with 97.4 per cent accuracy. At the time of publication, Google had not responded to a request for comment about the paper.But Jason Polakis, assistant professor in computer science at the University of Illinois who cracked reCAPTCHA version 2, notes that there's more to v3 of reCAPTCHA than the work described in the paper. "The attack that this paper attempts to demonstrate is simply moving from a random starting point in the page to the checkbox," he says. "That is a very specific and limited subset of the interactions a user will have with an actual page in practice (e.g., filling out forms, interacting with multiple page elements, moving across more complicated patterns, etc)."He adds: "If Google has also improved the use of more advanced techniques like browser/device fingerprinting (indications of which we had found when we did our extensive in-depth analysis and breaking of ReCaptcha v2), an attack will be even more complicated in practice."Akrout agrees that the mouse-movement based attack has limits, but those reveal a bit about how reCAPTCHA v3 works. "If you're connected with your Google account from a normal IP, then the system most of the time will return that you're a human," he says. Connect via TOR or a proxy, and you'll be reported as a bot more often than not.Most PopularThe Big StoryPriscila, Queen of the Rideshare MafiaBy Lauren Smiley, WIREDPoliticsTrump Shooting Conspiracies Are Coming From Every DirectionBy David Gilbert, WIREDPoliticsFar-Right Extremists Call for Violence and War After Trump ShootingBy David Gilbert, WIREDSecurityAT&T Paid a Hacker $370,000 to Delete Stolen Phone RecordsBy Kim Zetter, WIREDKnowing that makes it easier to force a reCAPTCHA system to show the "I am not a robot" button, if the website in question has been set up to default to it. Akrout says the attack requires appearing neutral to Google — so no logged in accounts, but not coming in via a proxy or using browser control tools such as Selenium, either. "It's as if I'm asking the system to go directly to the second [page], just to get the mass movement detection," he says.Akrout adds there are easy ways Google could protect reCAPTCHA from this technique, notably tracking the amount of time a user takes to click the button. "The agent spends more time than humans to click on the checkbox," he noted. "Anyone can always leave reCaptcha working in the background without any interaction," adds Akrout, leaving his attack unworkable.Shujun Li, professor of cyber security at the University of Kent, has previously designed his own systems to crack earlier versions of reCAPTCHA, but wasn't involved in this project. He says the work looks technically sound, but added that Google would be able to update its system easily to avoid the proposed attack. "It remains unclear to what extend the proposed attack can be retrained to catch up," he said. "A potentially more robust approach would be to collect real human users' responses to reCAPTCHA and build a machine learning model to simulate such responses, which can be easily retrained and will be guaranteed to work unless reCAPTCHA becomes unusable for normal human users."Indeed, there's plenty of other ways to crack these systems, Li notes. While this particular attack may be limited, the fact that reCAPTCHA would continue to fall prey to artificial intelligence systems isn't a surprise. "It has not been news that CAPTCHAs are crackable. Recent AI advances have significantly improved success rates of automated attacks," Li added. "In principle, CAPTCHA as a technology has proved unable to resist advanced attacks." This particular research may not crack reCAPTCHA v3, but it's a start.This article was originally published by WIRED UKEnter your email to get the Wired newsletterclose dialogRecommended NewsletterFast ForwardA weekly dispatch from the future by Will Knight, exploring advances in AI and other technologies set to change our lives. headline: Google's reCAPTCHA test has been tricked by artificial intelligence
author: [{'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'Nicole Kobie', 'sameAs': 'https://www.wired.com/author/nicole-kobie/'}]
articleBody:
CAPTCHAs are the tests used by websites to battle back against bots, asking website visitors to prove they're human before proceeding. The leading system is Google's reCAPTCHA, which has previously asked website visitors to prove their humanity by checking words scanned from books or photographs of street signs. Such systems have been hacked before. Indeed, the text and image based CAPTCHAs have been so frequently cracked that researchers in China and Lancaster University dubbed their paper on generative adversarial networks "Yet another text CAPTCHA solver". The accessible audio version was even targeted using speech-to-text tools to listen to the audio clips and upload an answer.
But that all got harder at the end of last year, when Google revealed a CAPTCHA-less reCAPTCHA. Rather than unpicking garbled text or street signs, or even ticking a box that a website visitor is not a robot, version 3 of reCAPTCHA analyses a range of signals, giving a score between zero and one. Lower scores are more likely to be bots, while higher scores are more likely  to be human.
That ranking happens entirely in the background; there's no human interaction at all. Google hasn't explained what goes into the bot-or-not score — no surprise, as hackers would be sure to make use of that information — but it appears to include the browser used, IP address, and whether they're logged into a Google account. After all, if Google knows it's you, it knows you're not a bot.
That system hasn't yet been hacked, despite the title claim of the authors of a recent paper, "Hacking Google reCAPTCHA v3 using Reinforcement Learning." Instead, Mohamed Akrout, of the University of Toronto, and his co-authors focused on tricking a secondary system with machine learning. The invisible scoring system isn't abused, but nevertheless they claim they could still get past reCAPTCHA v3.
In reCAPTCHA v3, websites set their own score threshold for what they are willing to consider a bot or not. If a visitor falls under that threshold at a set point, such as when they're entering a review or login details, the website has two options, says Akrout. The first is to immediately show a page denouncing that visitor as a bot, which is a little awkward if the system is wrong and it's a human; imagine working your way through an online purchase to suddenly have the page you're looking at disappear and be shown a "You're a bot" accusation out of nowhere. "This is a bad practice from a user experience perspective," says Akrout.
Instead, Akrout says, many sites choose to negotiate the process a little more kindly. If a website visitor falls below the bot-or-not threshold, the site will surface a page with the older style "I am not a robot" checkbox, letting humans better understand why their online shopping experience or whatever else was interrupted and giving them a chance to prove their humanity.  "Most programmers I know add checkboxes because they don't know how to choose a time at which they ask v3 about its belief." By that, he means that version 3 has a constant score; websites can access it at any time. Do it at random, and a site will suddenly stop working.
Read more: Captcha is dying. This is how it's being reinvented for the AI age
And it's in that gap that Akrout and his fellow researchers strike. The "I am not a robot" checkbox was introduced in version 2 of reCAPTCHA, analysing behaviour including mouse movements to spot bots. The researchers have created an automated system that can fool that part of reCAPTCHA.
It's not directly addressing version 3's invisible scoring, but the mouse-movement analysis first introduced in version 2 — but because of how the system is implemented on some websites, it doesn't have to fool the newer system. In other words, they've found another way around reCAPTCHA using AI but it isn't quite as grand as promised.
That doesn't convince Nan Jiang of the University of Bournemouth, who wasn't involved with this research. "Theoretically, any CAPTCHA scheme purely relying on examining user behaviour can be hacked with tailored machine learning algorithms as such algorithms can be used to simulate a real user’s interaction on a page easily," he notes. "However, Google ReCAPTCHA… combines other technologies to predict how much a client can be trusted and then try to whitelist that client. Once you get whitelisted, whatever you do will still allow you to pass the test."
Akrout and his fellow researchers fool the one section of reCAPTCHA using a type of machine learning called reinforcement learning, in which a software agent tries to find the best possible path, encouraged via rewards for each step it takes in the right direction. Their system lays a grid of squares across the page, working the mouse diagonally through the grid towards the "I am not a robot button". Given positive reinforcement if it's successful and negative if not, the system learns the right ways to move to convince reCAPTCHA the mouse is being controlled. The paper claims it works with 97.4 per cent accuracy. At the time of publication, Google had not responded to a request for comment about the paper.
But Jason Polakis, assistant professor in computer science at the University of Illinois who cracked reCAPTCHA version 2, notes that there's more to v3 of reCAPTCHA than the work described in the paper. "The attack that this paper attempts to demonstrate is simply moving from a random starting point in the page to the checkbox," he says. "That is a very specific and limited subset of the interactions a user will have with an actual page in practice (e.g., filling out forms, interacting with multiple page elements, moving across more complicated patterns, etc)."
He adds: "If Google has also improved the use of more advanced techniques like browser/device fingerprinting (indications of which we had found when we did our extensive in-depth analysis and breaking of ReCaptcha v2), an attack will be even more complicated in practice."
Akrout agrees that the mouse-movement based attack has limits, but those reveal a bit about how reCAPTCHA v3 works. "If you're connected with your Google account from a normal IP, then the system most of the time will return that you're a human," he says. Connect via TOR or a proxy, and you'll be reported as a bot more often than not.
Knowing that makes it easier to force a reCAPTCHA system to show the "I am not a robot" button, if the website in question has been set up to default to it. Akrout says the attack requires appearing neutral to Google — so no logged in accounts, but not coming in via a proxy or using browser control tools such as Selenium, either. "It's as if I'm asking the system to go directly to the second [page], just to get the mass movement detection," he says.
Akrout adds there are easy ways Google could protect reCAPTCHA from this technique, notably tracking the amount of time a user takes to click the button. Shujun Li, professor of cyber security at the University of Kent, has previously designed his own systems to crack earlier versions of reCAPTCHA, but wasn't involved in this project. He says the work looks technically sound, but added that Google would be able to update its system easily to avoid the proposed attack. "It remains unclear to what extend the proposed attack can be retrained to catch up," he said. "A potentially more robust approach would be to collect real human users' responses to reCAPTCHA and build a machine learning model to simulate such responses, which can be easily retrained and will be guaranteed to work unless reCAPTCHA becomes unusable for normal human users."
Indeed, there's plenty of other ways to crack these systems, Li notes. While this particular attack may be limited, the fact that reCAPTCHA would continue to fall prey to artificial intelligence systems isn't a surprise. "It has not been news that CAPTCHAs are crackable. Recent AI advances have significantly improved success rates of automated attacks," Li added. Title: 80% of Indian engineers not fit for jobs, says survey - Business Today
keywords: Indian Engineers,Engineering Graduates,Annual Employability Survey 2019, Aspiring Minds,Employability,Tech sector,Artificial Intelligence,AI,Machine Learning,ML,Data Science
og:description: The new Annual Employability Survey 2019 report by Aspiring Minds reveals that 80% of Indian engineers are not fit for any job in the knowledge economy and only 2.5% of them possess tech skills in Artificial Intelligence (AI) that industry requires.
twitter:description: The new Annual Employability Survey 2019 report by Aspiring Minds reveals that 80% of Indian engineers are not fit for any job in the knowledge economy and only 2.5% of them possess tech skills in Artificial Intelligence (AI) that industry requires.
author: [{'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'BusinessToday.In'}]
articleBody: There has been no change in the employability prospects of Indian engineering graduates in the past nine years, with only a handful of them possessing next-gen tech skills, according to the new Annual Employability Survey 2019 report by Aspiring Minds.The report reveals that 80% of Indian engineers are not fit for any job in the knowledge economy and only 2.5% of them possess tech skills in Artificial Intelligence (AI) that industry requires.The report highlights that the the ad-hoc changes in the Indian higher education system would not help address the problem, it rather needs a systematic and fundamental change to deal with high unemployability numbers.Also Read: Amidst worsening job crisis, fresh engineers in India struggle to find work &quot;The government of India needs to prioritise higher education and undertake long-term policy interventions in the next 5-10 years to ameliorate the low rate of engineering employability,&quot; the report suggests.It also states that only a handful of Indian engineers possess coding expertise. &quot;Good coding skills are possessed by 4.6% of Indian job applicants.&quot;The report, however, says that Indian engineers (4.6%) can code correctly compared to their Chinese counterparts (2.1 %) but lag far behind American peers (18.8 %) who can write codes correctly.Also Read: Skill gaps affecting Indians' prospects in tech jobs, says IBM chief Ginni Rometty The report further adds, &quot;If we consider only those candidates who can write correct code with few errors, the gap between China and India narrows (8.6% vs. 9.8%, respectively),&quot;Interestingly, while the percentage of Indian engineers who code well is greater than the number of Chinese engineers, a much higher proportion of Indian engineers (37.7%) cannot write a compilable code compared to Chinese engineers (10.35%). This means that India must do more to educate its general population in proper coding skills, the survey underscores.Meanwhile, the US engineers perform four times better than the Indian engineers in coding, with only 4% of them not able to write comilable code despite the fact that the base of the engineering population in the US is approximately four times smaller than in India, the report mulls.Also Read: What went wrong with Indian higher education It further emphasises that the Indian engineers need to move beyond basic coding skills to keep up with the demands of the 21st century. The tech industry needs graduates to be equipped with skills in AI, Machine Learning (ML) and data science to keep up with the changing requirements of the sector.The findings underline the sorry state of affairs in the engineering education parlance which is mainly theory-based where only 40 % of students perform internships while only 36 % undertake projects beyond their required coursework.The survey further stresses on the lack of industry exposure amongst students. &quot;Students are trapped in a college bubble. They have little industry exposure. Only 47% of students attend industry talks. Sixty percent of faculty do not discuss how engineering concepts apply to industry,&quot; it rues.Also Read: Good news for engineering students! Wipro plans to double campus hiring this year The report recommends that the concerns at hand can be addressed by a mix of counseling programmes and technology including AI along with tools that can aid students assess their skills, find company matches and prepare for interviews accordingly.&quot;Our students need counseling to understand the kinds of jobs that are available; how to determine which job profiles match their interests and skills; the skill gaps that may disqualify them; and how to address those skill gaps.&quot; It concludes.
name: 80% of Indian engineers not fit for jobs, says survey
